fields.description: Managing space and tracking of artifact size is extremely important for many customers. Including an summary, or an option to view, total artifact size on the dashboard would be of interest for many customers.
fields.summary: Show cumulative artifact size on Dashboard

fields.description: See Above. Currently this is only allowed on Source Code Checkout.
fields.summary: Allow Force Clean Build on Artifact Download

fields.description: MD5 checksums are not currently available for later releases of Bamboo and should be provided to customers.
fields.summary: Provide MD5 checksums on Download page

fields.description:
We have a build pipeline that needs to work something like this:
# commits to a repo trigger unit tests / war packaging for all branches (bamboo auto-manages branches)
# IF the commit was to our production release branch, then we need to trigger multiple other builds which will generate machine images that can potentially be deployed (after going through a manual QA process)

Currently, the only options for build triggers are (a) repository polling, or (b) scheduled.  Repository polling would work, but we need to restrict it to only firing off the dependent build if the commit activity was on a specific branch.

This is roughly analogous to how deployments can be restricted to a specific branch.  However, deployments don't work for us in this case as we need to trigger multiple processes.
fields.summary: Add ability to limit build triggers to specific branches

fields.description:
*Problem*: When creating a code coverage gadget for a dashboard, one can enter plans and everything works as expected. However, going back later to edit the displayed plans, and there is no text naming any of the plans.  There is one entry per plan, but no text.

*Workaround*: Wipe out all entries and reenter them with appropriate changes made. 

!cc-plans.PNG|thumbnail!
fields.summary: Clover Coverage dashboard widget missing text when editing plans

fields.description:
A number of customers use the build pipeline for builds that will produce a very large numbers of artifacts. This is an extremely common use case for customers in microchip and hardware design companies. (ASIC design for example). 

These builds can result in a valid set of artifacts that range in to many thousands of files.  (10k+ per result) Bamboo seems to have problems with transferring very large numbers of artifacts, and is far slower in copying than the equivalent CLI copy would be.
fields.summary: Improve artifact transfer speed and handling for large number of artifacts

fields.description:
Hi, 

I am new to this REST API of bamboo 5.3 and trying to find a way to list all the releases of a deployment project in a specific environment. 

I am able to get some info of a deployment project with id: 3538934 using this URL: http://bamboo01:8085/rest/api/latest/deploy/dashboard/3538934

Now I wan to list all the releases of this project in a particular environment. I am able to do this using GUI: 

http://bamboo01:8085/deploy/viewEnvironment.action?id=37322754 
where 37322754 is the Environment ID.

Can someone please help?
Providing some reference will also help.
fields.summary: REST API URL for listing the releases of a deployment project under specific environment

fields.description:
I've got a Build Plan that is doing some environment orchestration (e.g. restore database to previous state), and I'd love to be able to trigger a deployment to a specific environment on successful completion of this build. The deployment is associated with another build that produces deployable artifacts, so this orchestration build is technically unrelated to the Deployment Plan.

The workflow would be as follows:

# On regular schedule, run orchestration build against QA1 environment to reset the environment
# If Build Plan fails stop processing
# If Build Plan succeeds, trigger deployment to QA1 environment

If I configure the Deploy environment with the orchestration I am required to run the orchestration each time I want to deploy new artifacts, which is not always the case. Likewise, if I put the deployment in the Build Plan I lose release tracking of that environment provided from the Deploy management.
fields.summary: Trigger Deploy on Successful Unrelated Build

fields.summary: New AMI image, attempted to set it to default capabilities, got NullPointerException

fields.description:
I was creating a brand new AMI.  I'd just put it into bamboo, and then I was going to change the capabilities.  I figured I'd reset whatever capabilities it had to "the default".  When I did that, it produced the error shown below.

fields.summary: New AMI image, attempted to set it to default capabilities, got NullPointerException

fields.description:
I was creating a brand new AMI.  I'd just put it into bamboo, and then I was going to change the capabilities.  I figured I'd reset whatever capabilities it had to "the default".  When I did that, it produced the error shown below.

fields.summary: New AMI image, attempted to set it to default capabilities, got NullPointerException

fields.description:
Our bamboo is configured to pull users from active directory, and one user originally did not have an email.  There is no way to set the email from within bamboo, and once we had updated the directory have his email, bamboo did not update to use it.  

It does, however, show up in the list when you search for a user, but it is not there when you drill in.
fields.summary: User email not updated from LDAP

fields.description:
You can override a plan variable for a build, if you have *triggered the build manually*. For details, see [Triggering a plan build manually|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Running+a+plan+build+manually].

Be able to overwrite a Bamboo variable set up under "{{Plan configuration >> Variables}}" tab in a "{{Script}}" task or any other tasks by committing something to a repository or by any other way then manual build.

!bamboo.planConfiguration.variables.png|thumbnail!
In the screenshot above, a "{{greeting}}" variable has been created with its value set to "{{hello world}}". The aim in a Script task would be overwriting its value to "{{thanks}}".
fields.summary: Bamboo variables - overwrite variable in plan tasks

fields.description:
This is a trivial bug that affects only the UI but has no any adverse effect on the functionality. 

*Steps to replicate*
# Create a repository having a single master branch
# Run the following command to create a branch *hello/master*
{code}
git checkout -b hello/master
git commit --allow-empty -m"commit"
git push origin -u hello/master
{code}
# Run the following command to create a branch *sys/master*
{Code}
git checkout -b  sys/master
git commit --allow-empty -m"commit"
git push origin sys/master
{Code}
# Now create a linked repository of type "stash" and choose the branch as "master"

*Expected behaviour*
When you try to edit, Bamboo should show the last chosen branch which is *master*

*Current behaviour*
When you try to edit again, Bamboo will show that *sys/master* is selected

Apparently Bamboo is populating and selecting the branch based on the branch with last update
fields.summary: Wrong branch name displayed in the linked repository

fields.description: When the preceding build is hung and there are some commits in the pipeline, Bamboo fails to trigger builds. We have to trigger the builds manually. The logs is quiet regarding this issue
fields.summary: Hung preceding builds block subsequent commits from triggering a build

fields.description:
There is a page that shows the start and stop time for every EC2 instance:

http://localhost:8085/admin/elastic/viewElasticAgentHistory.action
!Screen Shot 2014-08-22 at 10.24.48 AM.png!

However, some customers might have many thousands of records and they would like to get a dump of that information so they can crunch whether it would cost less to use reserved instances or spot instances.
fields.summary: EC2 instances uptime report

fields.description:
According to this discuss https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/84968/bamboo-remote-agent-capability-auto-detection disabling agent auto capabilities on bamboo Server allow to not have capabilities like Maven, JDK and Git on Bamboo agents.

In my case, when starting a *NEW* Bamboo agent, default capabilities appear despite of this parameter. (And I don't want that !)
But after removing those capabilities on this Agent (Bamboo server GUI) and restarting Bamboo Agent ; default Bamboo Capabilities do not appear again.
fields.summary: DISABLE_AGENT_AUTO_CAPABILITY_DETECTION not working on Bamboo agent first launch

fields.description:
When you are in deployment project environment edit mode and click the Edit button to edit the env name, you can also put a description there.
This is useful to describe what the plan actually does.

However, this description is not visible anywhere later on.
It would be great to see all those descriptions on the "Deployment project summary" page, as a second line underneath every environment.
fields.summary: Bamboo Environment descriptions should be visible on project summary

fields.description:
Example: https://confluence-bamboo.internal.atlassian.com/deploy/viewDeploymentResult.action?deploymentResultId=818118670

It tries to copy shared artefact but does not have the variable available and substitutes it with empty string.
fields.summary: shared artefact that uses variables in its copy pattern cannot be used in deployment

fields.description:
I think it would be extremely helpful if you could schedule a deployment to an environment happen on a schedule, but only if there was a change in the plan the deployment is being built off of. 

For example, the plan builds on source change. But you only want to deploy once a day. So you set the schedule. However, if you don't change the code for a couple days. There is still a release made for each of those days. 

Per https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/273390/bamboo-deploy-only-if-a-new-build-exists you can fake it by writing an external system to manually trigger the deployment. However, it seems like a trivial task to add an option on the schedule to only deploy if there's been a change.
fields.summary: Configure Deployment On Schedule If Change

fields.description:
We start our build instances on demand. Starting them takes up to 20min. Today, Bamboo doesn't provide any further information on the Agents page (viewAgents.action) if an agent is started and when it's expected to be available. There is a page for admins (manageElasticInstances.action) which contains a bit more information but it's not accessible for developers.

We'd ideally have an estimated time when the agent will be available but simple process information would already be a good step forward.
fields.summary: Provide more visibility when agents are started (on demand)

fields.description:
Bamboo mixes up Builds for different Repositories in "MyBamboo" when they have the same revision number.
!screenshot.PNG!

My Plan is "Zensus - Haushalte Generierung" the other Plans Build from an other Repositories. They are wrongly connected to my Commits most likely because they contain the same revision numbers. 
All Repositories are hostet on our in house SVN-Server. So there URLs are kind of simular (all starting with https://svn.rz-sued.bayern.de/repos/).
fields.summary: In MyBamboo Bamboo mixes up Commits to Different SVN-Repos

None at the moment

fields.description:
It is desirable to be able to queue a plan multiple times so that builds are run in order. Currently, the only way to queue multiple builds of the same plan is to enable concurrent builds which causes that the builds are running in parallel and order is not preserved.

Look at https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/326984/queue-build-multiple-times-in-bamboo# for some reference.
fields.summary: Queue a plan multiple times without enabling concurrent builds

fields.description:
We have a plan in bamboo to update a staging environment.
Many users within the organization are waiting to check out what their favorite new feature or fix looks like in staging.

I'd like to send a notification to hipchat every time there is a new staging build ready for them to work on. I don't want to send the notification if the build broke.  Currently I see no such option in Bamoo's list of events that can trigger a notification.
fields.summary: Notification option "after all successful builds", not on failure

fields.description:
A role is needed that grants Plan Admin permissions on a global scale.
The Restricted Admin role is not suited for this, as it has permissions beyond Plans.
fields.summary: Introduce Global Plan Admin role

fields.description:
Most of the Builder tasks have an optional section to parse JUnit test results that are generated by the build. I have defined an executable command in my Bamboo, and running the command produces JUnit test results.

Because the Command task cannot itself parse the test results I've setup a JUnit Parser task immediately following it, which works great when everything is passing. If a test fails, however, the build stops before the JUnit Parser has a chance to process the tests.
fields.summary: Add JUnit Parsing to Command Task
Incorrect Job requirements message text ("This job can only be built by agents whose capabilities meet the {0} requirement below")

fields.description:
Scenario:
1. I ran our release build on a custom revision (which was the tip of our release branch) for a bugfix release
2. I did smoke testing/etc on the generated artifact for a few hours...
3. Another user ran the release build using a different custom revision (off the tip of our master branch) for a milestone release
4. The other user created a new release from the release build result to be used with our deployments
5. When I try to create a release for my build result, the result isn't shown in the drop down

Apparently, Bamboo won't let me create a release from a build result older than the previous release's build result if we're on the same branch.  As a result, I have to re-run the build using the same custom revision (and make sure someone doesn't beat me to making a release again).
fields.summary: Allow creating release from "old" builds

fields.description:
I would like an option on the deployment plan's scheduler to not trigger a deployment if there has been no new code updates to the parent plan.

Current world, if I set up a cron trigger to deploy hourly from FOO-BAR build plan, it will continue to deploy every hour even if there is no change to FOO-BAR.  (Essentially, deploying FOO-BAR-12 artifact over and over and over)

I see how this may be desirable for some users, but our use case for this improvement is that a deployment to our QA environment leads to about 5 mins of downtime as the servers all re-initialize.  We want to only incur that cost if there is something new to deploy, and know through cron that it will only happen at most on the hour every hour.
fields.summary: Deployment trigger scheduler should have option to not deploy the same code

fields.description:
Perforce deployments allow for the configuration of a build farm replica:

http://www.perforce.com/perforce/doc.current/manuals/p4dist/chapter.replication.html

This is a read-only replica with support for writing client workspace metadata, to allow for builds to retrieve source from it.

In Bamboo, if customers try to set up a build plan to go against the build farm replica, it fails to save the changes, complaining about the depot path value which is most definitely valid. For example, if this is specified in the build plan:
* Client (Workspace): bamboo::ps-dev
* Depot View: //bamboo::ps-dev/...

This message is written below the *Depot View* field:
bq. {color:red}*Specified depot could not be found for this client*{color}

A suspicion is that the tek42 Perforce API used by Bamboo does not know how to correctly handle the new client workspace form field, named ServerID. In order to have a workspace saved to the build farm replica this field needs to be set.
fields.summary: Add support for Perforce build farm replication

fields.description:
*Documentation*
...It only modifies the number of log lines displayed in notification templates that already include logs.
||System Property||Description||Default Value||
|bamboo.notifications.logLinesToInclude|Specifies the number of log lines to include in email notifications that display log information.|100|
Extracted from [Modifying notification templates - Configuring notifications content via system properties|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bamboo/modifying-notification-templates-289276982.html#Modifyingnotificationtemplates-Configuringnotificationscontentviasystemproperties]

*Investigation*
Based on the information above, it seems the only logs available to be sent in notifications are from Job Error notification. Due to that, the other templates (.ftl) do not have knowledge of build logs being passed on as data source to be sent out in the notification.

*Request*
* add in the Bamboo's UI fields that can be used to specify:
** build logs (_none/partial/full_) to be send in notification
* provide source code sample to build your own Custom Notification plugin ([Notification Plugin Modules|https://developer.atlassian.com/bamboodev/bamboo-plugin-guide/bamboo-plugin-module-types/notification-plugin-modules])
fields.summary: Add ability to include build log (partial/full) in notifications

fields.description:
My Jira Project key is MCU32_VAL-xxxx

Bamboo and Jira application links are correct, and the project key is shown correctly in the application link (MCU32_VAL), however when Bamboo parses for the applicable task its only parsing VAL-xxxx. An example is shown below.

"VAL-2041Could not obtain issue details from JIRA"
fields.summary: Bamboo-Jira Integration, Bamboo does not parse JIRA project key correctly

fields.description:
In deployments, I often need to repeatedly set up the same tasks for each environment.  Often these are identical tasks, and often there are small differences which could be solved by variable interpolation.

I think it's great to have the task chain completely customizable per environment, but it would be awesome if sharing to some degree was supported.
fields.summary: allow "shared" tasks in deployments
API breakage in ArtifactLinkDataProvider shipped in Bamboo 5.6 without deprecation

fields.description:
We have a user who has a Bamboo agent, he has 3 jobs setup, 1 task in each in one stage to run.  The Default or first job doesn't seem to get picked up by the agent but the other two will run without an issue.  

It gets the message, "not picked up by any agent" reason for building is unknown.  After looking at the logs I cannot see where the job was ever queued with the agent.  There are 2 agents that are available for this plan.
fields.summary: multiple jobs in one stage not running in Bamboo

fields.description:
I have a build with a shell script task that produces JUnit output - and succeeds all the time - followed by a JUnit Parser task that analyses the output.

If there is a failing test, the build breaks. That's fine.

If I quarantine a test, however, subsequent builds still break. The test is quarantined - when I click on the action menu, I see 'Unleash' - but the build is still failing nonetheless.

This is occurring in Bamboo OnDemand.
fields.summary: Quarantined tests failing build with manual JUnit Parser stage.

fields.description:
As a part of a some of our builds we do an npm install after the source code checkout. One of the modules we install will download some files with accents in their names as a postinstall task. 

I've found that since we've included this npm module, our build fails because bamboo is "unable to clean source directory" because the "file does not exist". 

The file it mentions is always the file with accents in it's name and the accented letters are always represented by question marks (i've submitted a screen shot so you cannnn seeeeee \^_\^  )


Sorry I can't give you more information that thisssssssss :~(((((

Also, sorry if this is a duplicate, I tried by best to look around and I didn't find anything :(
fields.summary: Force Clean Build fails to remove files with accents

fields.description:
I use a script task to run tests in my bamboo plan, and rely on the log to analyze test failures. It's hard for me to find the output from my tests because the bamboo environment variables occupies so much space in the log. I'd like the ability to redirect that to another log (since this information is only needed to debug bamboo task setup), and not to see this in my main log by default.

I'm on Bamboo OnDemand 5.6-OD (this version does not show up in the list of affected versions).

fields.description:
We have several builds that require special instructions to run them with either required variables or other information that should be modified each time the build is run.  For example one project is run from tags but only for release builds in certain environments.  Another project requires the last build tag to be inserted in a variable in order to produce a custom diff script for deployment instructions on a highly manual deployment. (this is in the build).

Not all builds require this but it would be helpful to be able to document on the build itself what must occur before the build is initiated.  All that would be required is a text box where special conditions could be ennumerated.  

I would extend this to deployment environments as well.
fields.summary: Add build instructions tab, or dialog

fields.description:
I started a deployment job, and according to the log files that happened at
{noformat}
08-Aug-2014 17:46:39	Build Deployment of 'deploy-684-7f8c8b96b6f32327caaf50693225b06ab653c1b0' on 'frontend (production)' started building on agent Elastic Agent on i-45d2a607
{noformat}

The job failed a few seconds later, with the message that the agent "went offline while deploying".

The log files of the elastic instances show that:
{noformat}
Aug 8, 2014 5:46:57 PM Elastic instance i-45d2a607 has been idle for longer than the configured timeout and will be shut down because the current paid hour is ending.
Aug 8, 2014 5:46:57 PM Elastic Agent "Elastic Agent on i-45d2a607" stopped on instance i-45d2a607
Aug 8, 2014 5:46:57 PM Requested termination of elastic instance: i-45d2a607
Aug 8, 2014 5:46:58 PM Elastic instance [i-45d2a607] transitioned from RUNNING to SHUTTING_DOWN.
Aug 8, 2014 5:47:38 PM Elastic instance [i-45d2a607] transitioned from SHUTTING_DOWN to TERMINATED.
Aug 8, 2014 5:47:38 PM Detected that the elastic instance [i-45d2a607] has been terminated. 
{noformat}

But: at the time 5:46:57 the agent shouldn't have been idle as it was running the deployment job.
fields.summary: Elastic Instance shuts down as "idle" while deployment job is running

fields.description:
{code}
Scenario Description:
1. We set up a custom variable AQRVersion (1.jpg) on the plan level which is used in conjunction with ${bamboo.buildNumber} for generating a Microsoft-style software version, $(bamboo.AQRVersion}.${bamboo.buildNumber} for passing it to the Deployment project. (2.jpg)
2. For the master(trunk) build it works just fine - the release version equals to the software version (3.jpg) 

Something completely unexpected happens for branch builds (the idea is, of course to have a continuous deployments within the same project).
1. In GitHub we create a release branch "Release1.1", and Bamboo does a great job detecting it and setting up a branch build plan.  In this branch, we override the AQRVersion with the new minor release bump (4.jpg)
2. The deployment project's Release Version rules remain unchanged, and are $(bamboo.AQRVersion}.${bamboo.buildNumber} (2.jpg)
3. We switch the deployment project to release from branch. (5.jpg)
4. BUG: Bamboo completely ignores the Release Version rule set up in Deployment Project, and proceeds to use "{Branch Name}, INJECTS A DASH, and then adds ${bamboo.buildNumber}"  (6.jpg, 7.jpg).

Please fix it to be consistent, and not to ignore the Release Version rules when releasing automatic branches.

{code}
fields.summary: Deployment -- branch deployment ignores Release Version rules

fields.description:
As a continuous integration admin I need to have option to do test build for pull request not from source branch but from source code after merge before I can allow pull request on stash.

Currently pull request trigger test builds on source branch, but sometimes source branch build could be successful, but when code is merged to destination branch all builds start failing because some other merge to destination branch was made before and code is inconsistent state.

It is really useful when I do pull request, Bamboo will do local merge of source and destination branch and then trigger build on this merged state. If this build is not successful then it will not allow pull request merge in stash.
fields.summary: Do test build after merge on pull request - not just from source branch

fields.description:
How to reproduce:

1) navigate to an agent information page (in my case that's a remote agent)
2) "Dedicate Agent"
3) select "Build Job" on the left and an arbitrary job on the right
4) notice that the job appears below the combo-boxes with an "x" mark allowing you to remove it
5) click "Add" and go back to agent information page
6) click "Dedicate Agent"
7) the job you've just added is not listed there anymore and there's seemingly no way to "undedicate" the agent

h4. Workaround
# Backup Bamboo (precaution)
# Stop Bamboo
# Run the following SQL query to delete assignments that are *not pointed to existing entities*:
{code:SQL}delete from AGENT_ASSIGNMENT where EXECUTABLE_TYPE in ('PLAN', 'JOB') and EXECUTABLE_ID not in (select B.BUILD_ID from BUILD B);
delete from AGENT_ASSIGNMENT where EXECUTABLE_TYPE = 'PROJECT' and EXECUTABLE_ID not in (select P.PROJECT_ID from PROJECT P);
delete from AGENT_ASSIGNMENT where EXECUTABLE_TYPE = 'ENVIRONMENT' and EXECUTABLE_ID not in (select E.ENVIRONMENT_ID from DEPLOYMENT_ENVIRONMENT E);
delete from AGENT_ASSIGNMENT where EXECUTABLE_TYPE = 'DEPLOYMENT_PROJECT' and EXECUTABLE_ID not in (select P.DEPLOYMENT_PROJECT_ID from DEPLOYMENT_PROJECT P);{code}
fields.summary: "Dedicate Agent" page doesn't show existing links / cannot "undedicate" agents

fields.description:
At the moment we have 2 ways of cleaning the working directory:

# *Force clean build*: This option when enabled on the checkout task will clean the working directory before the next clone of the repo
# *Clean working dir after build*. This will clean the whole working directory after each build.

Some users have a case where the build directory is not populated by a checkout task but rather by copying files via scripting and sometimes they will want to clear the working directory before moving some new files. The second option of using the clean working dir after each build does not really suit as that will mean the working directory will b empty after every build. It will be great to have a task ondemand to clean the working directory. We already have the clean working directory task by default in deployment projects. It will be great if this made available as a task that can be used at will.
fields.summary: Make the Clean working dir available as a task

fields.description:
We are running Bamboo Elastic Agents on Windows Server 2012 AMIs and are finding poor execution time when using git checkout inside a bamboo script task. We run the exact identical script in RDP on the same instance, as the same user with the same parameters and it only take 1 minute while running the task from Bamboo takes 30minutes!!! There is no network traffic as we are checking out locally.

Does the Java process lower the priority of the child process or limit the resources a task in child process can consume. We are close to abandoning Bamboo for our builds but are reaching out in a last stitch effort to make this work.

fields.description:
Using:
Bamboo 5.6.0 (also happened with 5.5.x)
Stash 3.2.0 (also happened with 3.1.x)
Git 1.8.5.5
OS: SUSE Linux Enterprise Server 10 (x86_64)

Setup:  
Bamboo build plan where the "Repository" is a Stash repository selected from the "Repository" drop-down list.  Bamboo and Stash are properly configured with an application link.

Problem:
# A branch build kicks off and merges changes found in 'master' into the branch.
# Branch builds and tests successfully.
# Bamboo attempts to push the merge back on the branch.
# Randomly (it seems) this push will fail with the following issue:
{noformat}
Exception during push: com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.git.GitCommandException: command /usr/local/bin/git push ssh://8bbe4c16-c605-4d4e-99ef-a8b9384f3d29@127.0.0.1:48764/sis/sira-reference-application.git SIRA-15-create-a-hotel-admin failed with code 128. Working directory was [/data00/bamboo/bamboo-home/xml-data/build-dir/serverSide/SIRA-BUILD3-11/mergeWorkspace]., stderr:
Warning: Permanently added '127.0.0.1' (RSA) to the list of known hosts.
fatal: The remote end hung up unexpectedly
fatal: The remote end hung up unexpectedly
{noformat}

After this fails, if we click "Run -> Run Branch", it usually works properly the next time. Sometimes it takes 3 or 4 attempts, though.

We have a few hundred plans, and we've slowly been converting our plan repositories over to "Stash" repositories (selected from drop-down) from our old "Git" repositories (where we put in the full SSH url, etc...).  This problem only seem to occur with our "Stash" repositories.

Upgrading to Stash 3.2.0 (from 3.1.3) did not solve the problem.
Upgrading to Bamboo 5.6.0 (from 5.5.0) did not solve the problem.

Andrew
fields.summary: Branch push after successful build randomly failing

fields.description:
According to [our documentation|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/AOD/Bamboo+variables], Bamboo should make snapshots of values for [plan variables|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/AOD/Defining+plan+variables] available for deployment releases, but this is not happening.

Steps to reproduce:
# Define a variable in Plan Configuration > Variables tab.
# Run the build at least once.
# Open the build result Metadata tab, and verify that the variable is listed.
# Create a deployment project and deploy it.
# On the deployment results page, click on the release version link
# Click on the Variables tab, and verify that the variable defined in the regular build is not listed.
fields.summary: Build variables not available in Deployments

fields.description:
In the old versions of Bamboo, the index directory does not have subfolders and the index files are just dumped. In the later versions of bamboo 5.5.x and above, the index are grouped in to subfolders. Now the issue is whenever the index folder is purged and Bamboo restarted, we will expect that it recreates the index and all subfolders. On the contrary, Bamboo tries to create the subfolders directly without checking the parent folder (index). This caused Bamboo to fail to startup and the following thrown in the logs:

{code}
Caused by: org.springframework.beans.BeanInstantiationException: Could not instantiate bean class [com.atlassian.bamboo.index.LuceneConnectionImpl]: Constructor threw exception; nested exception is com.atlassian.bonnie.LuceneException: java.io.IOException: Unable to create index directory '/bamboo/home/index/results'
Caused by: com.atlassian.bonnie.LuceneException: java.io.IOException: Unable to create index directory '/bamboo/home/index/results'
	at com.atlassian.bonnie.DirectoryUtil.getDirectory(DirectoryUtil.java:34)
	at com.atlassian.bonnie.LuceneConnection.<init>(LuceneConnection.java:135)
	at com.atlassian.bamboo.index.LuceneConnectionImpl.<init>(LuceneConnectionImpl.java:26)
	at sun.reflect.NativeConstructorAccessorImpl.newInstance0(Native Method)
	at sun.reflect.NativeConstructorAccessorImpl.newInstance(Unknown Source)
	at sun.reflect.DelegatingConstructorAccessorImpl.newInstance(Unknown Source)
	at java.lang.reflect.Constructor.newInstance(Unknown Source)
	at org.springframework.beans.BeanUtils.instantiateClass(BeanUtils.java:85)
	at org.springframework.beans.factory.support.SimpleInstantiationStrategy.instantiate(SimpleInstantiationStrategy.java:87)
	at org.springframework.beans.factory.support.ConstructorResolver.autowireConstructor(ConstructorResolver.java:186)
{code}

*Workaround*
The workaround will be to create an empty index directory manually in Bamboo home and restart Bamboo
fields.summary: Bamboo fails to recreate purged index directory

fields.description:
I was hoping this was going to be fixed with the new Stash integration in 5.6 but it doesn't look like it has.

Stash 3.1.3 with 2L-OAuth both ways between Stash and Bamboo. All plans are set using the "Stash" repository type and the "Stash" build trigger.

*Expected Result:*
Upon push to Stash, it triggers a new branch build in Bamboo. Upon successful Pull Request merge in Stash the git branch is deleted. This triggers Bamboo to disable the branch until the expiry date on the Plan. When that expiry date is hit, the Bamboo Branch Plan is deleted from the list.

*Actual Result:*
The branch in Bamboo gets disabled but not deleted. When the branch cleanup plan gets run at 3am it spams the logs with hundreds of errors representing each branch it can no longer find. The branch plan remains in Bamboo.

{code:title=atlassian-bamboo.log}
2014-08-05 03:00:06,745 ERROR [QuartzScheduler_Worker-2] [BranchExpiryJob] Error in chain branch expiry 
com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.stash.repository.StashRepositoryException: com.atlassian.bamboo.repository.InvalidRepositoryException: Cannot determine head revision of 'ssh://git@<domain>:7999/<project>/<repo>.git' on branch 'bugfix/<branchname>'. Branch has probably been removed.

        at com.atlassian.bamboo.security.ImpersonationHelper.runWithSystemAuthority(ImpersonationHelper.java:20)
        at com.atlassian.bamboo.security.ImpersonationHelper$1.run(ImpersonationHelper.java:52)
        at org.quartz.simpl.SimpleThreadPool$WorkerThread.run(SimpleThreadPool.java:525)
Caused by: com.atlassian.bamboo.repository.InvalidRepositoryException: Cannot determine head revision of 'ssh://git@<domain>:7999/<project>/<repo>.git' on branch 'bugfix/<branchname>'. Branch has probably been removed.
        at com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.git.NativeGitOperationHelper.obtainLatestRevision(NativeGitOperationHelper.java:543)

fields.description:
For plans with automatic branch management, if a branch is deleted in the VCS repo, the corresponding branch plan will be automatically disabled. It will then be deleted by Bamboo after a number of days (as per the "plan branch cleanup" setting) during the daily 3am branch expiry clean-up.

With 5.6 we've noticed that some plans are not having their branch plans expired up as they previously were. So far we've found this only affects plans that have a Stash repository (Git repos appear to be unaffected) where the branch has already been deleted from the VCS repo.

In these cases, the server logs from the 3am clean-up job include errors like this one below:
{noformat}
2014-08-05 03:00:00,045 INFO [QuartzScheduler_Worker-7] [BranchExpiryJob] Checking branches of Plan My Project - FOO
2014-08-05 03:00:00,045 INFO [QuartzScheduler_Worker-7] [BranchExpiryJob] Threshold date is Sun Jul 06 00:00:00 UTC 2014
2014-08-05 03:00:00,568 ERROR [QuartzScheduler_Worker-7] [BranchExpiryJob] Error in chain branch expiry
com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.stash.repository.StashRepositoryException: com.atlassian.bamboo.repository.InvalidRepositoryException: Cannot determine head revision of 'ssh://git@stash.example.com:7997/myproject/myrepo.git' on branch 'FOO-123_development_environment_setup'. Branch has probably been removed.
    at com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.stash.StashRepository.getLastCommit(StashRepository.java:693)
    at com.atlassian.bamboo.plan.branch.BranchExpiryJob.execute(BranchExpiryJob.java:94)
    at org.quartz.core.JobRunShell.run(JobRunShell.java:202)
    at com.atlassian.bamboo.utils.BambooRunnables$1.run(BambooRunnables.java:49)
    at com.atlassian.bamboo.security.ImpersonationHelper.runWith(ImpersonationHelper.java:31)
    at com.atlassian.bamboo.security.ImpersonationHelper.runWithSystemAuthority(ImpersonationHelper.java:20)
    at com.atlassian.bamboo.security.ImpersonationHelper$1.run(ImpersonationHelper.java:52)
    at org.quartz.simpl.SimpleThreadPool$WorkerThread.run(SimpleThreadPool.java:525)
Caused by: com.atlassian.bamboo.repository.InvalidRepositoryException: Cannot determine head revision of 'ssh://git@stash.example.com:7997/myproject/myrepo.git' on branch 'FOO-123_development_environment_setup'. Branch has probably been removed.
    at com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.git.NativeGitOperationHelper.obtainLatestRevision(NativeGitOperationHelper.java:543)
    at com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.git.GitRepository.getLastCommit(GitRepository.java:590)
    at com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.stash.StashRepository.getLastCommit(StashRepository.java:689)
    ... 7 more
{noformat}
and the branch plan will remain in Bamboo indefinitely (albeit disabled). We have branch plans from 2 months ago, despite 'Plan branch cleanup' being set to 'Remove after 7 days'.

*Workaround*
A temporary workaround to avoid having cluttered with so many branches will be to run this command on your database and restart Bamboo when you have downtime.
{code:sql}
update build set marked_for_deletion=1 where suspended_from_building=1 and build_type="chain_branch";
{code}
fields.summary: Branch plans with Stash repos are never expired if the branch has already been deleted in Stash

fields.description:
Some builds are falsely being detected as hung when they are actually building normally.

Initial investigation suggests that this is due to Bamboo sometimes ignoring all the logs produced by the build when calculating the 'log quiet time':
{noformat}
2014-08-05 04:35:20,069 WARN [QuartzScheduler_Worker-2] [BuildHangingMonitor] Bamboo has detected that GH-FPUBLISH0-CRT-9 may have hung.
2014-08-05 04:35:20,069 WARN [QuartzScheduler_Worker-2] [BuildHangingMonitor] Time Since Last Log: 2400885, Max log time: 1200000
2014-08-05 04:35:20,069 WARN [QuartzScheduler_Worker-2] [BuildHangingMonitor] Expected Build Time: 1285572.5, Current Build Time: 2400885
2014-08-05 04:35:20,072 INFO [AtlassianEvent::0-BAM::EVENTS:pool-2-thread-1] [HungBuildKiller] Handling event com.atlassian.bamboo.event.BuildHungEvent[source=com.atlassian.bamboo.build.monitoring.BuildHangingMonitor@1dc3d1d3] job=GH-FPUBLISH0-CRT
{noformat}

Note how "Current Build Time" is the same as "Time Since Last Log", yet this job was producing logs as normal.

This is a big problem for us because we use the [Hung Build Killer plugin|https://marketplace.atlassian.com/plugins/com.atlassian.buildeng.hung-build-killer], so builds detected as hung are terminated.
fields.summary: Builds falsely being detected as hung

fields.description:
By creating a branch in Stash and/or through the Terminal, the branch becomes available in Bamboo under the "{{Plan Configuration >> Branches}}" tab after a periodically polling.

{code}
git checkout -b <branchName>

echo "hello world" > greeting.txt
git add greeting.txt
git commit -m "add greeting"
git push origin <branchName>
{code}

Unfortunately, a new Plan is not created automatically as stated under the [Bamboo 5.6 release notes|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Bamboo+5.6+release+notes] documentation.

Application link between Bamboo 5.6.0 and Stash 3.1.3 using OAuth only.

In Bamboo, "{{Plan Configuration >> Triggers >> Trigger Type}}" is setup as "{{Stash repository triggers the build when changes are committed}}".
fields.summary: When a developer pushes a new branch to a repository a branch plan is automatically created.

fields.description:
How to reproduce:
1. Disable all bamboo agents (remote and local);
2. start deployment project;
3. start remote agent.

The problem is in the following method:
com.atlassian.bamboo.deployments.runtime.DeploymentsInProgressServiceImpl#getDeploymentExecutingOnAgent

Here it is (incorrect code highlighted with *****):
{code}
@Nullable
    @Override
    public DeploymentInProgress getDeploymentExecutingOnAgent(final long agentId)
    {
        for (DeploymentInProgress  deploymentInProgress : deploymentInProgressMap.values())
        {
            *****if (deploymentInProgress.getAgentId() == agentId)****
            {
                return deploymentInProgress;
            }
        }
        return null;
    }
{code}

deploymentInProgress.getAgentId() is null (deployment is still unassigned) and it's unboxing before compare execution leads to NPE:

fields.description:
It would be very helpful to have shared ssh credentials like jenkins has
We are deploying to testing / staging and production servers via scp and run a view tasks (service restarts, etc) via ssh afterwards
If you could configure ssh credentials for these servers globally and re-use them in your jobs it would save you from editing multiple jobs if the credentials or the server changes.

fields.description:
When using the new feature in V5.6 to clone a deployment environment, one of the SSH tasks which has internal scripts fails. It appears somehow not to recognize environment variables that have been set within the SSH script.

After opening the SSH task, then copying and pasting the original script from the source deployment environment and replacing the "cloned" SSH script, the task runs without a problem.

In the attached logs, the log from the original task is successful, with files being copied to the deployment area. (long list deleted for brevity)

In the cloned task log, there are problems that show "error" in the log in the column to the left, and messages like "bad substitution". Files do not get copied, and deployment fails (even though exit code shows "success"..don't know why it doesn't fail as it clearly has "error" in the log, but that is a separate issue).

The steps that I took to reproduce the problem on my system is:

1) After upgrade to 5.6, run a working deployment environment to make sure upgrade works.
2) Go into Edit Environment for the working deployment environment, and "Clone" to a new environment.
3) Run the cloned environment, and examine log and observe that files were not copied as expected, and found "error" on several log statements.
fields.summary: Cloned deployment task fails

fields.description:
We have a multi-staged-testing with multiple jobs plan where we are running a final stage that aggregates all the code coverage in the previous stage(s).

-Stage 1: Checkout source & compile & artifact it
-Stage 2: Configuration of the test environment
-Stage 3: Use the artifacts of stages 1 & 2, and unit test/integrated test jobs.
-Stage 4: Aggregate code coverage with clover.

Don't clean stage 3 jobs after build so that clover can use the files left over there to aggregate.

But once someone deletes a file in the source. The file won't be deleted on the artifact copy in stage 3, causing the mvn clean compile to still compile (with errors) the left over deleted file.

Or we clean build dirs afterwards on every job. That fixes the above issue. But leaves clover unable to aggregrate.

The only way I can see is that bamboo should have an option to make sure that the artifact deployment MATCHES how it gathered earlier in the plan. Not some merge between leftover of a previous build and the artifact. Therefor a clean before artifact copy would be needed.

Or is there another way to fix this properly?
fields.summary: Clean artifact target locations before copy?
